content.question: The position of a particle moving in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane is given by the parametric equations <math alttext="x of t, equals, e to the negative t power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and <math alttext="y of t, equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, 4 t, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> for time <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>. What is the speed of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 1.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.2</mn></mrow></math> ?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.6: (BC ONLY) Solving Motion Problems Using Parametric and Vector-Valued Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
